_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank, furse tanks, shutoff valves, safety relief valves, plumbing, breakaways, hoses and liquid pump

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY-CARROLL SERVICE COMPANY FORRESTON FACILITY

Note that this facility was the property of BLACKHAWK FS and they have since gone out of business and the NH3 Tank is now leased from its new owner.  Also note that this plant is manned in season only.                                              

1. Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of Carroll Service Company are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should accur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minnimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.

The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammona is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 140,000 pounds, this would include the large tank and the nurse tanks.

3. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of Safety Requiarements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.

4. Five year accident history.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at th

e facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The emergency response program.

The facility has:
-a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);
-a written emergency response plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

7. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is and on=going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safetly recommendations for implementation at this time.


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR A NURSE TANK

The storage of an anhydrous ammonia nurse tank is 1,000 gallon.  The maximum pounds that can be stored is 5,000 pounds.  The nurse tanks are left on site.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1. Published by The American National Standards Institue, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.  Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident program.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
-Have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor
-To our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter inplace, property damage, or environmental damage.

The emergency response program.
The facility has:
-a written eme

rgency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)>

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Forreston Fire Department and the Ogle County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and the Ogle County LEPC.

Planned changes to improve safety:
Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
